pages:
Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 43182  
Regional—Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
December 2009 
 
 
 
Improving the Health Status of Vulnerable 
Communities Threatened by Legacy or Artisanal 
Pollution  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  HPF  –  health and pollution fund 
  NGO  –  nongovernment organization 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA) 
Targeting classification  –  Targeted intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Health and social protection (health systems, waste management)  
Themes (subthemes)  –  Social development (human development), environmental 
sustainability (environmental policy and legislation), capacity 
development (institutional development) 
Location impact  –  Rural (medium), urban (medium), national (medium), regional (low) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  U. Schaefer-Preuss, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development  
Director General  X. Yao, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
Director  B. Edes, Poverty Reduction, Gender, and Social Development Division, RSDD 
   
Team leader  J. Jeugmans, Practice Leader (Health), RSDD 
Team member  V. Joshi, Environment Specialist, RSDD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Environmental  degradation  aggravates  poverty  and  makes  growth  unsustainable.1 
Recognizing  the  links  between  health,  poverty,  and  polluted  environment,2 Strategy  20203 
reiterates  the  need  to  assist  developing  member  countries  in  addressing  environmental 
problems. Environmental damage not only reduces quality of life, but has significant costs for 
public health—with the poor most severely affected. Pollution-related morbidity and mortality, 
including  productivity  losses—notably  among  infants,  young  children,  and  women—are 
pervasive in the region.  
 
2.  The technical assistance (TA), Improving the Health Status of Vulnerable Communities 
Threatened  by  Legacy  or  Artisanal  Pollution,  will  focus  on  the  adverse  health  impacts  of 
industrial  pollution  sites,  in  particular  those  in  which  the  polluter  responsible  is  either  not 
available (legacy pollution) or too small (often of the artisanal variety) to be charged with the 
costs of cleanup. These toxic sites are usually in poor neighborhoods; affect millions of people 
(especially children); and give rise to birth defects, genetic problems, mental retardation, and 
cancers. They often are not identified by health and environment officials and the public. The TA 
aims to raise awareness of the problem and explore possible solutions to address these issues 
in the region. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Polluted sites can be found in all poor countries, and industrial areas with poor pollution 
controls can be found in many developing countries. Wastes from the chemical, metallurgical, 
and processing sectors frequently contain toxic substances such as heavy metals, solvents, and 
organic compounds. Illegal dump sites of various chemical toxins can be found in urban and 
suburban areas; they frequently pollute local water supply and may enter the food chain. Many 
residents of areas around tanneries and stainless steel factories must rely on groundwater 
polluted  with  cancer-causing  hexavalent  chromium  as  their  only  choice  for  drinking  water. 
Informal and unregulated battery processing facilities pollute urban areas with lead. These 
pollutants affect the lives and health of people mainly in the developing world, where regulations 
are weak and enforcement difficult.  
 
4.  The damaging health effects of toxic substances are well known: drastically shortened 
life spans, retarded mental and physical development, cancers, respiratory diseases, stomach 
and  skin  lesions,  and  psychiatric  disorders.  The  adverse  impacts  of  toxic  pollution  are 
particularly severe on children. They play outside and are exposed to larger doses of toxins than 
adults. Smaller bodies, coupled with maturing biological systems, also accumulate higher doses 
per unit of mass, causing greater harm. Certain pollutants can permanently damage brain cells 
and nervous systems in young bodies. The longer these problems are left unaddressed, the 
more  children  are  harmed.  Toxic  pollution  seriously  stunts  the  economic  prospects  of 
developing countries.4 
 
5.  Toxic wastes—postconflict and industrial toxic wastes—are present across Asia, but the 
scale of the problem is unknown. Some international nongovernment organizations (NGOs) are 
                                                 
1  Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2008. 2007 Development Effectiveness Review. Manila 
2  P. Steele, G. Oviedo, and D. McCauley, Eds. 2007. Poverty, Health, and Ecosystems: Experience from Asia. 
IUCN, Gland, Switzerland and Asian Development Bank, Manila, Philippines. 
3  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
4  Blacksmith Institute. 2009. The Global Inventory Project. Training Packet. New Delhi.

2   
lobbying  Asian  governments  to  recognize  the  problem,  assess  its  importance,  and  take 
appropriate action. Some donors and development partners have indicated possible interest in 
supporting cleaning of toxic wastes in the region. The first step, however, is to better assess the 
importance of the problem. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will join the Global Inventory 
Project, a global effort to eliminate toxic wastes.5 The project is a joint effort supported by Green 
Cross Switzerland; the European Commission through United Nations Industrial Development 
Organization; and the Blacksmith Institute, an international NGO that partners with governments, 
NGOs, and community groups to identify and assess sites in more than 80 countries where 
pollution poses the greatest threat to human health, especially that of women and children. The 
main  objective  is  to  provide  data  to  governments,  international  organizations,  and  local 
communities that will enable them to prioritize clean-up activities and programs. The next step 
will be to identify appropriate mechanisms, including funding sources, to help clean up the toxic 
sites.  
 
6.  ADB will partner with an international NGO to build up local capacity in selected Asian 
countries. Local teams will follow a short training program, then will identify toxic waste in their 
respective  countries  and  assess  the  importance  of  the  problem.  In  parallel,  financing 
mechanisms will be explored—in particular the possible establishment of a regional fund—to 
help countries clean toxic waste legacy sites in the region. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  ADB’s goal is to ensure that people in the region live in a clean environment with no 
toxic  waste  in  the  proximity  of  human  settlements.  This  implies  that  governments  and 
development partners join forces with affected communities to clean up the existing toxic sites 
with active pollution or legacy pollution where the polluter is no longer available, and sites with 
artisanal pollution where the polluters are too small to take responsibility for the cleanup. This 
requires increased awareness and political commitment to put pressure on the polluters to 
reduce pollution and clean up their operations. 
 
8.  The TA will finance the first necessary steps to develop and implement an actionable 
strategy to clean up toxic sites in the region. The outcomes will be better information and 
awareness among policymakers, development partners, and the general public of (i) the scope 
of the problem: human and environmental damage caused by legacy and artisanal pollution in 
Asia and the Pacific (inventory) and preliminary cost estimates of cleaning up operations; and 
(ii) possible approaches to deal with the problem, including funding mechanisms (feasibility 
study for a health and pollution fund). 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The  TA  will  provide  better  information  on  the  scope  of  the  problem.  Applying 
methodologies developed by the Blacksmith Institute, the TA will develop a regional inventory of 
polluted sites in Asia and the Pacific, with an estimate of the populations affected at these sites. 
While the health risks are relatively well-known, the costs of cleaning up will be preliminary 
estimates based on ongoing clean-up activities of legacy and artisanal toxic sites around the 
world. As the clean-up techniques evolve, cost estimates will be revised and adapted. 
                                                 
5  The  Blacksmith  Institute.  2009.  The  Global  Inventory  Project.  http://www.blacksmithinstitute.org/blacksmith-
institute-to-lead-global-inventory-of-polluted-sites.html

3
 
10.  To provide governments and international partners with data that will enable them to 
understand the scope of the problem and prioritize interventions, the Blacksmith Institute trains 
and supports a team of investigators in the targeted countries to conduct initial site assessments 
of  polluted  sites.  Working  in  collaboration  with  local  and  national  authorities,  the  site 
assessment process reviews and collects as much information as possible from all stakeholders, 
including  local  NGOs,  businesses,  technical  agencies,  and  governments.  The  initial  site 
assessment protocol developed by Blacksmith involves a visit to the site and a review of key 
technical and historical information. Samples are taken, where credible tests are not already 
available, and information collected related to the population and pollutant. 
 
11.  A major challenge is to leverage the funds necessary to remediate the many polluted 
places where health is at risk. The envisaged mechanism for dealing with the sites identified 
through the inventory  process is a health and pollution fund (HPF). In October 2007, the 
Rockefeller Foundation and Blacksmith Institute organized a meeting in Bellagio, Italy, where 
donor agencies, international organizations, and developing country representatives discussed 
the problem. The meeting supported the idea of an HPF as a central trust fund to be mobilized 
with contributions from bilateral and multilateral aid agencies and private institutions. The trust 
fund could be housed at an existing multilateral agency, at an approved commercial bank, or 
other mutually acceptable host. 
 
12.  In discussions following the Bellagio meeting, some interested donors raised the idea of 
regional HPFs. In this context, the TA will support a team of consultants to explore options on 
funding framework, organizational structure, and operating principles for an HPF in Asia and the 
Pacific. Their proposals will be presented and discussed with all stakeholders in a regional 
workshop to be organized by the Blacksmith Institute in mid-2010. The workshop will be held in 
Asia, to be finalized in agreement with ADB. The objectives of this regional workshop will be to 
reach an agreement on the establishment of an HPF, including operating principles, and if 
possible start mobilizing resources for a regional HPF. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The Global Inventory Project started operations in February 2009 with funding from the 
European Commission and Green Cross of Switzerland; they pledged about $1.2 million over  
2 years on a grant basis to cover about 80 countries. ADB will join the Global Inventory Project 
through the TA and provide $900,000 on a grant basis from the Technical Assistance Special 
Fund (TASF-IV) to cover and expand activities in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA, with the Poverty Reduction, Gender, and 
Social  Development  Division  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department, 
responsible for TA implementation and administration. 
 
15.  The TA will cover Asia and the Pacific. However, activities funded by the TA will only 
commence in a particular developing member country after ADB receives a no-objection in 
writing from the government of the concerned country. 
 
16.  The TA will begin in December 2009 and be completed by December 2010. It will be 
implemented through the Blacksmith Institute, which will be engaged through single-source 
selection in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from

4   
time to time). Single-source selection is justified because ADB is joining the Global Inventory 
Project implemented by the Blacksmith Institute. Blacksmith will use the services of international 
and national experts on an intermittent basis: 19 person-months of international experts and 140 
person-months of national experts. 
 
17.  The Blacksmith Institute6 is a nonprofit organization committed to mitigating the human 
health effects of industrial wastes, air emissions, and hazardous materials in the developing 
world. The organization's strategy brings resources and expertise to local groups and agencies 
in  developing  economies  to  solve  pollution  problems.  Its  Technical  Advisory  Board,  which 
comprises a dozen experts in public health and environment, provides technical and operating 
oversight. The Blacksmith Institute is implementing the Global Identification and Evaluation of 
Pollution Sites project, started in January 2009 and financed by Green Cross Switzerland 
($447,426) and the European Commission through the United Nations Industrial Development 
Organization (€495,140). By recruiting the Blacksmith Institute, ADB and the region will benefit 
from global experience and information from other regions. Blacksmith’s contract with Green 
Cross  Switzerland  (signed  on  10  December  2008)  and  the  United  Nations  Industrial 
Development Organization (funded by the European Commission, signed on 21 January 2009) 
stipulates progress payments based on quarterly reports. The payments have  been made 
accordingly, reflecting Blacksmith’s capacity to manage the funds. 
 
18.  Disbursement  under  the  TA  will  follow  ADB's  technical  assistance  disbursement 
handbook. 7 Advance  payment  procedures  to  the  consultant  for  training,  seminars,  and 
conferences will allow timely implementation of activities. Progress payment will be made on the 
basis of quarterly reports. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis for 
Improving the Health Status of Vulnerable Communities Threatened by Legacy or Artisanal 
Pollution, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
                                                 
6  The Blacksmith Institute. http://www.blacksmithinstitute.org/ 
7 ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook. Manila

8  Appendix 3   
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
  
A.  International Consultants  
1.  Technical Advisors (10 international, 10 person-months) 
 
1.  The  technical  advisors,  engaged  intermittently,  will  generate  an  inventory  of  reports 
detailing pollution problems in each country through field visits based on the global inventory initial 
site  assessment  protocol.  The  technical  advisors  should  have  expert  knowledge  of  pollution 
problems and their effect on human health, be familiar with initial site assessment protocol, and be 
available to travel to different sites in Asia and the Pacific to undertake reviews of initial site 
assessments and help conduct training. The technical advisors will be responsible for 
 
(i)  reviewing  initial  site  assessments  completed  under  the  TA  for  integrity  and 
consistency of data; 
(ii)  recommending  on  the  integrity  and  consistency  of  data  to  relevant  regional 
coordinators and project managers, where necessary; 
(iii)  attending regional trainings and helping demonstrate initial site assessment protocol; 
(iv)  conducting on-site review of selected initial site assessments; 
(v)  ensuring that all expenditures are recorded based on the designated format by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB); and 
(vi)  preparing  monthly  reports  on  project  activities  for  submission  to  the  regional 
coordinator, Blacksmith Institute, and ADB.  
2.  Regional Coordinators (9 international, 9 person-months) 
2.  The  regional  coordinators  (under  this  TA,  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific  only),  engaged 
intermittently,  will  identify  and  manage  a  team  of  national  coordinators  and  investigators  to 
generate an inventory of reports detailing pollution problems in each selected country through field 
visits based on the global inventory initial site assessment protocol. The regional coordinators 
should have advanced knowledge of environmental health and accepted protocol for assessment 
of polluted sites, local knowledge of pollution issues in the region, and a good network of contacts 
related to toxics in the region. The regional coordinators will be responsible for 
 
(i)  identifying and managing national coordinators in each assigned country;  
(ii)  working with national coordinators to identify and hire a team of investigators of 
appropriate size and ability; 
(iii)  coordinating with national coordinators with respect to locations to be visited, time 
frames for visits, and other issues, as required;  
(iv)  ensuring that all expenditures are recorded based on ADB format; 
(v)  preparing monthly reports on TA activities within the assigned region for submission 
to Blacksmith Institute and ADB; and

Appendix  3  9 
(vi)  organizing training sessions for national coordinators and investigators to learn the 
initial site assessment protocols. 
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  National Coordinators (40 national, 40 person-months) 
 
3.  The  national  coordinators,  engaged  intermittently,  will  identify  and  manage  a  team  of 
investigators to generate an inventory of reports detailing pollution problems in each country 
through field visits based on the global inventory initial site assessment protocol. The national 
coordinators should have advanced knowledge of environmental health and accepted protocol for 
assessment of polluted sites, local knowledge of pollution issues in the assigned country, and a 
good network of contacts related to toxics in the assigned country. They will be responsible for 
 
(i)  identifying, hiring, and managing investigators in the assigned country; 
(ii)  working with regional coordinators to identify and hire a team of investigators of 
appropriate size and ability; 
(iii)  coordinating with regional coordinators with respect to locations to be visited, time 
frames for visits, and other issues as required; 
(iv)  coordinating with local authorities regarding access to sites and data related to sites;  
(v)  ensuring that all expenditures are recorded based on ADB format; 
(vi)  preparing  monthly  reports  on  project  activities  within  the  assigned  region  for 
submission to the regional coordinators, Blacksmith Institute, and ADB; and  
(vii)  organizing training sessions for local investigators to learn the initial site assessment 
protocols. 
2.  National Investigators (100 national, 100 person-months) 
 
4.  The national investigators, engaged intermittently, will generate an inventory of reports 
detailing pollution problems in each country through field visits based on the global inventory initial 
site assessment protocol. They should have local knowledge of pollution issues within the country, 
a good network of contacts related to toxins within the country, and ability to conduct initial site 
assessments quickly and efficiently. One site visit is expected to be reviewed in less than a day, 
including input to the online system of Blacksmith Institute. The investigators will be responsible for 
 
(i)  setting  up  meetings  at  potential  polluted  sites  with  appropriate  authorities  in  a 
professional manner; 
 
(ii)  coordinating with regional coordinators with respect to locations to be visited, time 
frames for visits, and other issues, as required; 
 
(iii)  attending training sessions to learn the initial site assessment protocols; 
 
(iv)  visiting  and  conducting  initial  site assessments  at  polluted  sites  throughout  the 
country, based on the protocols and systems developed by the Blacksmith Institute; 
and input data on the same day, as collected, into the Blacksmith online database;

10  Appendix 3 
 
(v)  ensuring that all expenditures are recorded based on ADB format; and 
 
(vi)  preparing  monthly  reports  on  project  activities  within  the  assigned  region  for 
submission to the regional coordinators, Blacksmith Institute, and ADB.
